meanings.definition: To clean or polish something by rubbing.
meanings.sent1: She clemmed the table until it sparkled.
meanings.sent2: I always clem my shoes before going out.
meanings.sent3: He clemmed the mirror so well, he could see his reflection clearly.
meanings.sent4: Her determination to clem the house shone through in every corner.
meanings.sent5: The old man's hands clemmed the silver to a brilliant shine.

meanings.definition: To make something clean or neat.
meanings.sent1: The maid clemmed the room quickly before the guests arrived.
meanings.sent2: I need to clem up my desk before starting work.
meanings.sent3: She always clemmed her workspace before starting a new project.
meanings.sent4: The sun's rays seemed to clem the sky after the storm passed.
meanings.sent5: The gentle rain helped clem the dusty streets of the town.

meanings.definition: To remove dirt or impurities from something.
meanings.sent1: The soap can clem the stains from the clothes.
meanings.sent2: I will clem the dishes after dinner.
meanings.sent3: The vacuum cleaner can clem the dirt from the carpet easily.
meanings.sent4: Her smile seemed to clem away the worries from his mind.
meanings.sent5: The river's flow helped clem the debris from the path.

meanings.definition: To make something free from dirt or impurities.
meanings.sent1: She used a special solution to clem the windows.
meanings.sent2: I like to clem my car every weekend.
meanings.sent3: The strong wind can clem the dust from the leaves.
meanings.sent4: His laughter seemed to clem the tension from the room.
meanings.sent5: The rain helped clem the pollution from the air.
